content: The Act may be cited as the "Denali Commission Reauthorization Act of 2012" and establishes the Denali Commission. The Denali Commission Act of 1998 is amended to specify the composition of the Commission, which will consist of 7 members with expertise in various rural Alaska matters. Five members will be appointed by the Secretary of Commerce, with one representing organized labor. The Denali Commission Act of 1998 is amended to specify the Commission's composition, including 7 members with expertise in rural Alaska matters. The members will represent organized labor, vocational training, Native Corporations, project management/construction, rural local government, and rural tribal interests in Alaska. The appointments of the Commission members shall be made within 90 days after the enactment of the Denali Commission Reauthorization Act of 2012. The Federal Cochairperson of the Commission will be appointed by the Secretary in accordance with the recommendations of the appointed members. The Federal Cochairperson of the Commission will be appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from the members within 60 days. The Federal Cochairperson of the Commission is a nonvoting member and any vacancy in the position will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Before vacating the position, the Federal Cochairperson will appoint an Interim Federal Cochairperson. The staff member with the most seniority will act as the Federal Cochairperson until a new one is appointed. Members of the Commission are not considered federal government employees except for the Federal Cochairperson. Members of the Commission are appointed for 4-year terms, with initial members serving varying term lengths. Vacancies on the Commission do not affect its powers and are filled accordingly. Vacancies on the Commission are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, subject to any conditions that applied initially. The individual selected to fill a vacancy serves the unexpired term of the member replaced, and no member's term expires before their successor takes office. SEC. 304 of the Denali Commission Act of 1998 is amended regarding funding requirements and duties. The Denali Commission Act of 1998 is amended to include cost-sharing requirements for construction projects, with up to 50% of total costs for general projects and up to 20% for projects in distressed communities. Preconstruction procedures are exempt from cost-sharing. Public comments are also required. The Federal Cochairperson is responsible for operational matters, including budgetary issues, of the Commission. The Commission is tasked with coordinating with rural Alaska communities, the State of Alaska, Federal agencies, and other entities, reviewing ongoing and completed projects for compliance, and examining projects for consistency and standardization to improve future management and success. The Denali Commission Act of 1998 is amended to allow interagency transfers for demonstration health projects, including hospitals, clinics, and mental health facilities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these projects. The Denali Commission Act of 1998 is amended to grant powers to the Commission, including the ability to detail federal employees without reimbursement and to enter into contracts and agreements. Commission personnel matters are also addressed. The Denali Commission Act of 1998 is amended to address compensation of members, with the Federal Cochairperson being the only member compensated at the prescribed rate. Additionally, a waiver provision is added for travel expenses, and the Commission is required to use the services of the Inspector General of the Department of Commerce. The Denali Commission Act of 1998 is amended to authorize necessary appropriations for the Commission to carry out its purposes for fiscal year 2013 and beyond. Additionally, certain sections are repealed. SEC. 7 of the Denali Commission Act of 1998 repeals certain sections related to exemptions and committees. SEC. 8 introduces a new Budget Committee. The Budget Committee, established under the Denali Commission Reauthorization Act of 2012, consists of 3 members with specific roles: the Governor of Alaska or a selected Commission member, a Federal budget expert, and a Commission member. The Committee's duties include reviewing the Commission's operating budget and making recommendations. The Budget Committee members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses while performing services for the Committee.
